109740: Deadwood Treefolk.author: _X_
109740: Deadwood Treefolk.text_parsed:
Love this card! Works great with eldrazi monument in EDH - on the turn you're supposed to remove your last time counter, sacrifice it to monument to return another creature to hand. If you can get him out of the grave, keeping even just non-token creatures on board with monument will be no problem.

And yeah - him and Woodfall Primus are butt-buddies 4 sho, but Deadwood and Eternal Witness combo by putting his wood on viagra! Throw a Skullclamp on eternal witness to "seal the deal" between the two graveyard lovers, conjuring a weird image of skulls and necrophilia.

110503: Waning Wurm.author: GrimjawxRULES
110503: Waning Wurm.text_parsed:
@fangster: Fading is almost like Vanishing, except that Fading gives you an extra turn. Vanishing kills the creature when the last counter is removed whilst Fading kills the creature only during your upkeep when there are no more counters on it.
Also, Fading uses >fadetime< counters. Since Time Spiral is all about the time counters, it makes sense to use Vanishing over Fading.
110503: Waning Wurm.text_posted:
@fangster: Fading is almost like Vanishing, except that Fading gives you an extra turn. Vanishing kills the creature when the last counter is removed whilst Fading kills the creature only during your upkeep when there are no more counters on it.
Also, Fading uses >fadetime< counters. Since Time Spiral is all about the time counters, it makes sense to use Vanishing over Fading.

110503: Waning Wurm.author: longwinded
110503: Waning Wurm.text_parsed: fangster: in addition to what Grimjawx said, they've moved away from fading in favor of vanishing. Apparently there is confusion among newer players, who sort of naturally expect that when you remove the last counter is when you should sacrifice the permanent. It's natural for new players to think of the counters as "this guy can stay in play" markers. Other players tend to forget that they need to sac it once the next upkeep rolls around: the pile of counters on the card is a good visual reminder that the creature needs to be tended to during your upkeep. Once the last one is gone, there's a whole turn (which in multiplayer can be a long time) to forget its days are numbered.

110536: Cradle to Grave.author: BrutalJim
110536: Cradle to Grave.text_parsed:
Strictly worse than Terror or Doom Blade.

@Silver: Pffft, unless your playing casually all the time and all your friends use esper decks, I highly doubt you're hindered by Terror's artifact restriction more often than the came into play this turn restriction from this. It's like a crap version of a counterspell, because you have to keep your mana open if you want to destroy a creature an opponent plays, and then you have to worry about stuff like protection from black, indestructibility, shroud, etc. In conclusion the only way Terror is ever worse than this mockery of a card is when every single creature in your opponents deck is an artifact creature, and even then it's not much better.

Terror and Doom Blade are both powerful, cheap creature destruction spells, this on the other hand is a very restrictive, retarded version of a counterspell.

111055: Lavacore Elemental.author: blurrymadness
111055: Lavacore Elemental.text_parsed:
I actually rather like this card. Combine with cheap tramplers (especially in multiplayer) and you're likely to keep it counter'd up. The 5 damage per turn, the constant card advantage if they block, or the fact that they'll spend removal on *this* causes issues for people. Nice thing is, they want to wait to spend removal until they see that you can get it to stick.

I recommend Reckless Charge, Fury Charm, Keldon Marauders. Proliferate can help, clock spinning is a 1-mana way to get him through. Distortion Strike

I want to point out that Distortion Strike does more damage with this guy than it does with Kiln Fiend; which is pretty impressive. Consider Reckless Charge + Dist. Strike for a total of 18 unblockable over 2 turns. Unfortunately it takes 5 mana; but it's quite doable on turn 3 with:

T1: Sandstone Needle
T2: Saprazzan Skerry, Keldon Marauders
T3: Mountain, Lavacore, Reckless Charge, Distortion Strike

Deals 1 damage, you swing for 3 and 9 unblockable. Flashback reckless charge and deal 1 as keldon leaves, you swing for 9 unblockable and have dealt 20 damage, pending removal/fog/etc..

111066: Chronozoa.author: masonthekiller
111066: Chronozoa.text_parsed:
I believe people are misinterpreting this card.

First, it has vanishing. When you remove the last counter, it's sacrificed. If I'm not mistaken, the sacrificing from vanishing only triggers if there are time counters removed from the permanent, thus if you Hexmage it you can't remove the last counter and sacrifice effect will happen and it doesn't go into the graveyard. That doesn't mean, however, there aren't other ways to toss it to the graveyard quickly.

Also, Cemetery Puca would become a copy of Chronozoa, but wouldn't get the time counters. You'd have to find another way to kill it or add time counters.

Followed Footsteps is an alright idea, but it's a waste of followed footsteps.

A nice combo I found with Chronozoa is with, of course, Paradox Haze, any creature with "Sacrifice a creature: This creature gets +X/+X" and Mortician Beetle. You can sacrifice a creature while the vanishing sacrifice is on the stack, so Chronozoa will have no time counters on it when you feed it to your eater to give it +x/+x, Mortician Beetle will get a +1/+1, and you get two more Chronozoa. Total cash.

111066: Chronozoa.author: sonorhC
111066: Chronozoa.text_parsed:
@shLt: Note that Doubling Season will also double the number of time counters they come into play with, meaning you'll have to wait twice as long before they split (and leaving that much more time for them to die while still having counters on them). Yes, believe it or not, there's actually a card that makes tokens that doesn't work well with Doubling Season.

And Splinter Twin would also be a poor choice, since the copies it makes will never get a chance to split unless you have some other way of removing the counters, and you'll lose the enchantment whenever the one you cast it on dies.

111066: Chronozoa.author: Frenzy13
111066: Chronozoa.text_parsed:
We have the pieces of the combo here, but we have yet to out them together:

Hex parasite. Mana Echoes. Soul Warden and Co.

Use hex parasite's X ability to remove the counters from chronozoa, producing the two copies. The soul warden's ability then activates regaining you the two life you lost from activating the ability. Mana Echoes then activates, adding mana equal to the number of illusions. If there are then at least 3 illusions, you will have enough mana to use the parasite's ability again.

Infinite Mana. Infinite parasite power. Infinite 3/3 flying giant protozoas. INFINITY!!!!!!!!!!!!!

122282: Revered Dead.author: yyukichigai
122282: Revered Dead.text_parsed:
Seeing both Spirit and Soldier on one card is overkill. Considering how much WotC has been pushing more tribal-based play, this makes this "colorshifted" card a lot more powerful than its original version. Soldiers have at least 4 "lord" creatures which pump them in various ways, while Skeletons only have Death Baron. Don't even get me started on Spirit creatures or Soulshift.

Given the strong tribal power, I'd say Revered Dead is more a colorshifted Walking Dead, though the Zombie tribal isn't anywhere near as strong as both Spirit and Soldier tribals combined.

On another note, when I first saw this card I took it to be the colorshifted version of Restless Dead rather than Drudge Skeletons. Restless Dead sounds a lot closer to Revered Dead at least.

122285: Shrouded Lore.author: DeadLeeCoC
122285: Shrouded Lore.text_parsed:
When you first see it, this card looks clunky and unwieldy... Now go over the list of cards in modern that return any card from your graveyard to your hand.

Any serious, stream-lined deck won't have to spend more than 2 mana to get back something that has already put a dent in the opponent. Cascading into it with Jund is just the icing on the cake for blightning/maelstrom pulse part two.

But on a sidenote: You shouldn't be filtering your graveyard for low powered cards, you should be using this to seriously reexamine your deck. If a card doesn't do anything to your opponent the first or second time you cast it, maybe you shouldn't be running that card.

122287: Rebuff the Wicked.author: Lief098
122287: Rebuff the Wicked.text_parsed:
Goes great in my B/W suicide deck to protect Phyrexian Unlife. Unfortunately, it does nothing against board-wide destruction or abilities. White countermagic is fantastic, though.

4.5/5.

@gtamaster503

No, you cannot counter a Cancel that is targeting a creature spell. While your creature spell is on the stack, it isn't a permanent; it only counts as a spell. Because your creature isn't a permanent until it resolves, Rebuff the Wicked can't counter the Cancel because the Cancel isn't targeting a permanent.

122287: Rebuff the Wicked.author: Palochka
122287: Rebuff the Wicked.text_parsed:
Braid of Fire's Card of the Day #15

When Turn Aside was printed and this was looked over, I understood, but I was very upset. Maro has talked about how counterspells are in white secondary more than a few times on his blog and elsewhere on the Internet, but other than the fantastic Lapse of Certainty, there haven't been any others since Planar Chaos.

Perhaps their uniqueness is what makes them so special. If we had a "common white taxing or reactive counterspell" in every limited environment, it would absolutely lose some of its magic, but I would still take that over our current model. Blue's monopoly on counterspells is defended to the death by R&D, but giving white low-impact ones could really create a depth in the color that wouldn't be stepping on blue's toes. UW has become the tempo pair according to R&D; what is more of a tempo play

I also should note that I love one mana spells and I love reactive spells from a design standpoint. Both are very difficult to craft effectively, but Rebuff the Wicked is a very strong design and has resonated with many players. The art is your standard proto-counterspell image, but still solid. This is just what a visual representation of a counterspell according to most artists. Maybe Terese Nielsen should have a crack at it again.

It should be noted that Faith's Shield essentially does the same thing as this with more room for upside, and in a more in-color method as well. Players really don't like seeing "counter target spell" very much, and R&D is a good listener. It's a shame though, really.

But man, what a perfect name for the card. Let's Rebuff the Wicked the next time we throw down some cardboard!

So it's gotta be at least three stars.

122324: Mana Tithe.author: BongRipper420
122324: Mana Tithe.text_parsed:
I love the concept of this card, so I picked up a few. After running it however, I realized the issues this card has can sometimes outweigh the benefits rather heavily. A few of which include;

1) For starters, this card is only good in your opening hand or within your first few draws. After turn 4 or so, it becomes a dead draw very quickly.
2) It's hard to find a balance of how many copies of this to run. Because it's only useful in the very early game, you want to run enough that you have it when it matters, but run too much and you top deck it in the late game after it becomes useless, and in the kind of control deck that runs this, there will be a late game usually.

That being said, this card can easily win you the game when it gets proper use. Anything your opponent taps out to play is likely important, and this makes sure they don't get to play it.

Also, a part of me really would like to test this out in a weenie deck. I feel like it could prove effective there, because there isn't much more than the early game, and your opponent practically has to tap out to keep up with you. Yeah, that turn 4 wrath? Isn't happening.

So in conclusion, this card is pure awesome... Until turn 5.

122338: Prodigal Pyromancer.author: Cybertronian
122338: Prodigal Pyromancer.text_parsed:
Just as Prodigal Sorceror's art reminded others of 'Tim' (or 'Timmy'?) from Monty Python, Prodigal Pyromancer's art reminds me of Hotstreak from the 90's Static comic series or the Static Shock cartoon based on it. (If he had Flash, he would be the comics version.)
Hotstreak was more fun during the Time Spiral block for red-blue players. There they could mix-and-match TS's Tim with PC's Hotstreak for random 1 dmg. pinging not limited to any one color.

122338: Prodigal Pyromancer.author: achilleselbow
122338: Prodigal Pyromancer.text_parsed: According to the "color pie" direct damage is strictly red. Back when Magic was new, the color pie existed but wasn't as well defined, which led to all sorts of interesting cards that wouldn't be printed today, like Psionic Blast.
122338: Prodigal Pyromancer.text_posted: According to the "color pie" direct damage is strictly red. Back when Magic was new, the color pie existed but wasn't as well defined, which led to all sorts of interesting cards that wouldn't be printed today, like [autocard]Psionic Blast[/autocard].

122338: Prodigal Pyromancer.author: Dragon_Nut
122338: Prodigal Pyromancer.text_parsed: Yes. To be specific, EVERYTHING that was considered tricky or manipulation was blue, which is part of the reason blue was so incredibly overpowered. That and the fact that instants and sorceries as a whole were much better whereas creatures were much worse. (Quick! Name three Alpha instants or sorceries played in vintage tournaments today! Now try and name 3 Alpha CREATURES. Yeah)

122349: Mantle of Leadership.author: DoragonShinzui
122349: Mantle of Leadership.text_parsed:
Don't really care for how this card works. The mechanics don't reflect the flavor very well.
First off, a leader isn't boosted by his buddies. A leader leads. This card doesn't really reflect that well at all.
Second, good leaders aren't just chosen on the spot. You don't just drop the mantle on 'em and POW, leader time.
Third, why on earth would you want an enchantment like this anyways? I suppose if you were pumping out a lot of soldiers, but there are better uses for pumping out those soldiers than just boosting one of 'em!
I would have preferred an enchantment that boosted everything BUT the enchanted creature. Not only does that make more mechanical sense, but that kind of backwards thinking is PERFECT for Planar Chaos.

122360: Calciderm.author: Tommy9898
122360: Calciderm.text_parsed:
Yeah, the vanishing is nothing to worry about at all. Most creatures die for what ever reason before it has been down for 2 turns so it has a much better survivability than other things; in addition, most non casual games don't last longer than 7 turns anyways so you don't have to worry about it dieing before the game is over.

Even more, you can use this effectively by having it as the only creature down under your control, most opponents will not be happy to wrath only one creature but they really won't have a choice, it needs to be answered. If it does finally die to fading, well it was down for 4 turns, you most likely would have topdecked another one by then.

It's all about the color.
Blue gets lots of good card draw. Green, despite it's official "second best at" title, - not so much. A plane-shifted Concentrate is much more valuable at the cost of 2GG than at 2UU. So, when you need some gas, but don't want to go blue for it, Harmonise is your good friend.
And what a beautifull art! Simple, but so-o deep. The same goes for flavour text. True wisdom there is.

122362: Harmonize.text_parsed: @SpencerDub: I see flavor of green drawing in a different way as the blue draw. Drawin of both colours can be seen as gaining knowledge, but from different sources. Blue focuses on progress, it wants to find out new ways, new means, it wants to move borders of mind... and it all comes from a power of mind and thoughts. Green, on the other hand, is much more spiritual. It takes it's knowledge from the harmony (so that harmonize...) and tranquility of nature, from its unchanging order, as well as from predatory rules of nature (I can think about Snake Umbra), you're getting to learn about a world by living... Green don't want the progress... green wants to learn about the world and understand it... both in watching falling leaves of trees or hunting a prey. I hope it makes sence :)

122366: Vampiric Link.author: chaz22
122366: Vampiric Link.text_parsed: if i place this on an opponent's creature does the owner of the creature gain the life?

122366: Vampiric Link.author: majinara
122366: Vampiric Link.text_parsed:
To answer the "do I gain life if I play it on an opponents creature" question: yes, you do gain the life, but only after the damage has been dealt. That means if you would die because by combat damage this turn, this enchant doesn't help you.
All in all, this card is too weak. Most of the time the enchanted creatures will be bounced, killed, pacified or whatever, and you lose two cards (creature + enchant) to one card (removal). Also, if you slap it on a small creature, the effect ain't worth it. If you slap it on a big creature, why don't you just attack with it and win?

122366: Vampiric Link.author: EnV
122366: Vampiric Link.text_parsed: Since the card does not contain the keyword "controller", and instead it says "you".   There is a huge difference between owning and controlling.   Despite an opponents creature being enchanted this still says "you."   Which is logic because your opponent never took control of the enchantment, and enchanting their creature does not cause them to own this enchantment.  Look up the rulings on this card it should make sense. And if the rulings don't help ask on the Wizards forums, come on people, this is pure logic!

122366: Vampiric Link.author: raptorman333
122366: Vampiric Link.text_parsed:
M10 rules changed so that life gain and damage dealt occur simultaneously, so this card's value went up a little.

@ClowWizardEriol: What are you talking about?! This card's ability is a triggered effect. Which means, if the opponent's creature that's enchanted with vampiric link can deal you a killing blow before the ability resolves, you lose! That goes for both combat damage and directe damage (e.g. {T}: Deal one damage to target creature or player.)... especially with machine guns like hermetic study + horseshoe crab, where vampiric link's ability goes on the stack after you get pinged, and then you get pinged again and again before any of the triggers resolve.

if i place this on an opponent's creature does the owner of the creature gain the life?
-chaz22
if the creature has an ability such as T "creature" does 1 damage to target player or creature, if he is enchanted with vampiric link does the controller gain that amount in life?
-Tnelis

to both chaz and tnelis: No, the controller of vampiric link is the one who gains the life. Since you cast it, you would control it unless someone played a spell to change that control (e.g. Aura Graft)

I propose that the stackable, written-out version of Lifelink be called "Spirit Link", in honour of the original card. Kind of like how some players still refer to Hexproof as "Troll Shroud".

It's interesting - one could argue that green's strength lies more in fatties than it does in weenies, and if you believe that, then this card is not quite as strong as Glorious Anthem - nowadays white is the king of strong, small creatures.

Still, whether you believe that or not, it's a great card! Green's options for enduring board-wide creature pump have been few and far between (Kaysa, anyone?), so I'm sure that when they printed this in Planar Chaos it was happily received by lovers of saprolings, insects, wolves, snakes... elves...

Wait, did I say the white version was better? Hm...

122370: Timebender.author: mrchuckmorris
122370: Timebender.text_parsed:
If Jhoira ain't your general, then this guy ain't for you.

Of course there are other, better cards out there for removing time counters, but none of them disguise themselves as potentially scary morph creatures. Aside from the fact that there aren't a whole lot of said time counter cards anyway, a Jhoira deck should be so filled with massive creatures that your opponents will be banging their heads against the table wondering where to spend their precious removal. Ending turn with 3 mana open will keep opponents guessing whether you're gonna suspend something else or un-morph that creature, and if they've forgotten all about the existence of Timebender, then they'll be in for a shock once you un-morph and pull in that eldrazi 2 turns early.

122373: Brute Force.author: Asmodi0000
122373: Brute Force.text_parsed:
With the way red has plenty of first strike/double strike creatures, this is definitely better in red than in green, since making a vanilla big creature bigger isn't all that exciting.

The key thing that makes this card great is that it increases toughness, a point where red tends to lack in a lot of cases. Also, it's nice to be able to save your creature from a bolt and then hit the opposing player for a nice extra three damage for his cheek.

The only problem is that Lightning bolt is the better card, just like how lightning bolt is better than giant growth. If you're running 4 lightning bolts, than it's alright to add this to your deck, but if you're running less, it's almost always better to just add another bolt.

122373: Brute Force.author: Brazz_Herald
122373: Brute Force.text_parsed:
Of all the "planeshifted" cards from Planar Chaos, this one has got to be the most damaging. Most people understand that green is not supposed to have flying, or blue is not supposed to have discard... but combat tricks? Every color has combat tricks. It's hard to focus on what makes this card come from an alternate reality, which is that this card is just a more powerful version of a combat trick for Red... you know... equal to Giant Growth, which is generally the best combat trick of any set it is printed in.

As players, power level is our blind spot. Many of us desire things to be better than they are, so they can go in our deck. We don't play with Red's combat tricks very often, because Red's removal is generally better. The tricks are printed as either a surprise, or as an interesting choice for limited. This card, though, can be arguably better than Lightning Bolt in some decks. It makes every other combat trick in Red look bad. It makes a bunch of players desire red to have combat tricks as good as green.

This wouldn't be a terrible problem... one color getting to do something about as well as the other colors spontaneously. The color pie gets moved around all the time. But, could you imagine if Planar Chaos did this to all the colors... giving them options that were just as good as good staples in normal standard? If Scryb Sprites returned, people would argue for green to having flying at cheaper costs... since they already did it with Scryb Sprites. If blue got a Mind Rot in Planar Chaos, people would start talking about how Blue should get better discard. What if White got Gravedigger?

The reason why my previous examples would have been bad choices for Planar Chaos is that they are very clean cards with exact ana1ogues to cards who do the job as well as them and are commonly played. Making Drudge Skeleton White or Master Decoy Black for a set isn't a big deal, since Drudge Skeleton and Master Decoy were never 5 star cards anyway. If Black got a Lightning Bolt, though, people would salivate for black to have more, since that card would be incredibly good. It's the same case with Brute Force. People only argue for Red to have P/T pumping this good because it happened once... and they aren't satisfied with the notion that it will never happen again.

122373: Brute Force.author: ugotpauld
122373: Brute Force.text_parsed:
i've changed a lot as a player since i wrote a comment on this last.
old comment -



anyway, i've learned the rules of the game (yay) and realised that combat tricks just aren't good in general.

dead draws with no creatures, and the extra damage you can cause to a player is often underwhelming as they have to be letting you hit them anyway, better to just be using burn.

often it can be card disadvantage as in response to you using this they can kill the creature, which is always pretty bad

the only deck i have with instant speed pumping now is my infect deck, purely because the card advantage and you get killing something with rot wolf is very nice and often worth these downsides.

anyway, pretty poor card, good in drafting as is every trick and just by not being green doesn't make a bad card good.

2.5/5 for surprise value alone.

Phasing is not being removed from the game. Exile is different. Phasing is still in play, but not able to be affected or targeted. This and Kismet only affect newly played perms. Phasing is one ability I wish would get reprinted. Even if they changed the name, à la Fading/Vanishing.

@Azazyel
Yes both would affect tokens. Kismet is older than most token decks, oracle might have not updated it as such. Even looking at the ruling for Frozen Æther, it shows this is the same card working the same way ... just updated in blue. Backwards logic would dictate that Kismet would affect tokens.

122406: Mirri the Cursed.author: Wulfsten
122406: Mirri the Cursed.text_parsed:
This card doesn't deserve the high praise it's getting. Although haste is nice, it's not difficult to get a blocker with 4 power out there on turn 4 or 5. It's also not difficult to kill her with direct damage or counters. Her Sengir ability doesn't come into play that often, unless the opponent is forced to chump block for some reason. She doesn't really threaten to do very much beyond deal 3 damage per turn, starting turn 4. Which actually isn't very frightening. Still an efficient and powerful card in combat, but at most a 4/5.

Ultimately, the infinitely superior vampire nighthawk costs 1 less mana, the infinitely superior vampire nocturnus costs the same, and, well, if you pay 1 more mana, get baneslayer angel.

122406: Mirri the Cursed.author: OlvynChuru
122406: Mirri the Cursed.text_parsed:
@Wulfsten

Vampire Nighthawk is NOT "infinitely superior" to Mirri. In fact, in some ways, Mirri is better.

"Although haste is nice, it's not difficult to get a blocker with 4 power out there on turn 4 or 5."

A FLYING blocker, you mean? You'd be surprised how difficult it can be to get out a creature that can block and kill this quickly enough. In order to do that, a creature needs to be able to block creatures with flying and have at least 3 power (remember that due to first strike Mirri gets a +1/+1 counter before the blocker deals damage to her). Besides, if they do get out a big blocker, just use your removal on it.

"It's also not difficult to kill her with direct damage or counters."

You could say the same about Vampire Nighthawk.

"She doesn't really threaten to do very much beyond deal 3 damage per turn, starting turn 4."

Except she is also a pretty good blocker. Not to mention that 3 damage per turn is actually quite a lot, for a single creature.

@NatalyNeeSama

She can fly because she is a vampire.

That made me think, most vampires turn into bats. So what would Mirri turn into? A cat-bat? A cbat? A bcat?

122408: Benalish Commander.author: DarthParallax
122408: Benalish Commander.text_parsed:
This seems to be a 'White Seige-Gang Commander'. Cool.

What I like about cards like this is that they allow you to do something really different- make a multi-tribal deck.

This card, all on it's own, can make a whole Soldier subtheme in your deck, at the price of no more than 4 card slots.

For an excellent example of how to take advantage of this opportunity, consider Kaalia of the Vast EDH. Sometimes it's fun to just go straight all-out Demons, Dragons, and Angels. But sometimes you want to go a bit bigger and more Epic than that. Sometims you wish you could have your giant flying beasts lead a huge army. Cards like this let you do that.

If you devote just a single space in your EDH deck to this card, you could wind up with a LOT of tokens.

Sure, not every game. Maybe not even every game you draw it. But the potential is there for him to become a one-card army. If you put a lot of different one card armies together, and then slap down a Coat of Arms, you can make a very epic battlefield. :)

@cheeseroll: this doesn't untap the creature.

122416: Sulfur Elemental.author: BlakeHN
122416: Sulfur Elemental.text_parsed:
I love Split Second, it basically says "you can't stop me!" (until they print something with 'T, Counter target spell: Add ~ to your mana pool.', which is funny, but unlikely)

I don't currently have any decks that I would feel comfortable playing this in, although, there are currently 360+ white creature cards that would die to this without assistance, so it's far from bad.

Maybe the biggest issue is: if you play this to get a boost then you may lose some guys in the process which cuts the effectiveness, but if you play it to wipe the board it's not guaranteed to do much either and whatever is left is going to hit you for more damage.

If you want a boost for your creatures, just use Celestial Crusader instead. Sure you may boost your opponents creatures too, but yours get the bonus too...
122416: Sulfur Elemental.text_posted:

If you want a boost for your creatures, just use [autocard]Celestial Crusader[/autocard] instead. Sure you may boost your opponents creatures too, but yours get the bonus too...

122416: Sulfur Elemental.author: Bbone37
122416: Sulfur Elemental.text_parsed:
@desertbuttons: of course the spell leaves the stack upon resolution. That's how spells are played, otherwise there would be no such thing as permenants. Split second only prevents people from responding to this being played. However, you cannot stop mana abilities, nor can you stop special abilities such as unmorphing a dude. Once this resolves and ETBs, then players can play spells as they normally would.

@Podunk_the_Mighty: I appreciate all types of players in magic, though I am far from a Vorthos, myself. However, if you play MTG solely based on flavor and how the cards make sense, then perhaps you should consider a different game. The cards dont have to make Earth-logic. This is a fantasy game. I suggested keeping your appreciation of the flavor of the game, but do not let it hinder your appreciation of the game as a whole.

@SAUS3: Tajic most certainly DOES care about toughness. Considering one of the few ways to kill an indestructable dude is to lower his toughness to 0, you are basically getting your opponent half way there for you. Not telling you what to do with your own deck, but keep in mind that just 1 more -X/-1 effect would indeed kill Tajic.

@BlakeHN: You are correct in that most things cannot stop split second, but do keep in mind that unmorphing Willbender or Voidmage Apprentice, can deal with the redirection/countering of split second cards.

122423: Damnation.author: Semptimilius
122423: Damnation.text_parsed:
Hm. I think the basic philosophy behind this card is one where black and white overlap. White reaches the destination by equal application of consequences, or fairness. Black reaches it by its tendency to hurt itself, along with others, in its quest for domination and power. In this sense, Wrath of God could just as easily have been black. With the appropriate name change... hence Damnation.

I'm not sure if every timeshifted card is so nicely mirrored.

122423: Damnation.author: ChaosK
122423: Damnation.text_parsed:
Destroying Creatures feels very black but creating balance by cleaning the WHOLE field is very white. So it fits both colors very well. People that dont understand why WoG is a white spell are ignorant.
Also in what it actually does, it has more defensive values and white always has been the main color for board effects especially mass removal.
I bet if WoG would have said exile instead of destroy, black players wouldnt argue about it being white.

Plague Wind for reference is definitly black and a white version wouldnt be flavorful

Also remember that this set is planar chaos, which is about color bleed, where for example, green gets non condotional card draw (Harmonize) and white direct damage (Sunlance). I am not saying damnation doesnt makes sense in black flavor wise (because it does) but R&D just decided that Board Sweepers like WoG belong to white in the color pie. (Mainly to balance the color pie - remember when blue used to be op in the old days?)

As a sidenote i recently had a 3HG Match with 2 Monoblack Zombie Players in my team. I used a white deck and when i casted a Day of Judgment one of them said: "wow its like a white damnation - thats funny" :D

122423: Damnation.author: myownworst
122423: Damnation.text_parsed:
One of the best black cards there is. It has been a long time coming for a card of this nature to be printed. The nature of the card fits with white but this card definitely makes sense in black. I have 4 in my deck and it is one of the cornerstones of how my deck functions. I just hope they never reprint it..they already have Wrath of God for that. I just wonder if there will ever be a black version of Armageddon printed.

What would REALLY be awesome is if there was some type of 'End of Days'' card where all players put all permanents that they control into their graveyards, then discard their entire hands, then all players exile their graveyards. There may already be one for all I know..

122428: Essence Warden.author: Narim
122428: Essence Warden.text_parsed:
Definitely better than Soul Warden... why? White is good at making tokens, but it can't match the elven token power... Lys Alana Huntmaster, Elvish Promenade, Hunting Triad, Prowess of the Fair.. and many, many more... and this weenie really provides you with a huge lifegain. It may be much more vulnerable than Leyline of Vitality... being able to be shot by virtually any removal, but is much more flexible and can be pulled much more easily. Put her first turn, then second turn Canopy Cover... and if you don't want to waste your aura on her, it's just trade of one opponent's removal vs your 1/1 which only increase your life. I would guess most opponents would save their removals for something else...

clearly at least 4/5 for me... she is not useful only in elven decks, but in any deck, and especially usefull when opponent is running creature heavy deck as well...

122429: Groundbreaker.author: Enelysios
122429: Groundbreaker.text_parsed: I love this thing. look closely at the art and you'll notice a guy being thrown off into the sky by it. to me the big advantage here is that I can play some of each in decks. However, to those who say that this is better than ball lighting because of green's mana acceleration? Desperate Ritual, Geosurge, Infernal Plunge, Pyretic Ritual, Rite of Flame and Seething Song beg to differ. Green has ramp, but red has rituals. This is one that I honestly think works better in red, but it's still hella fun in green, so it gets my vote of approval!

122429: Groundbreaker.author: BongRipper420
122429: Groundbreaker.text_parsed:
Next to green creature pump (Giant Growth, ect) this card seems significantly more terrifying than Ball Lightning. On top of that green has the ability to pump out multiples of these a bit too quickly thanks to all the ramp, as well as with Green Sun's Zenith .

Of course, Ball Lightning has the advantage of being fling-able while remaining in color. But why not just run both? For real, a play set of both will make an opponent cringe when every turn they're getting hit with a 6/1 trample haste, starting turn 2 with a Birds of Paradise.

122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: InsideousRakael
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
I really like this card when compared to its counterpart, Akroma, Angel of Wrath.
It's definitely a fair tradeoff.

Morph subs in for haste. I think it's better than haste overall, giving a cheaper way in and pseudo-haste when you flip her over.

I don't know why, but it feels like not being able to be countered is equivalent to Vigilance, but in a conceptual way rather than gameplay.

And, although in creature on creature combat Firebreathing isn't as valuable as First Strike, coupled with Trample it makes her that much more of a pain for the receiving opponent.
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_posted:
I really like this card when compared to its counterpart, [autocard]Akroma, Angel of Wrath[/autocard].
It's definitely a fair tradeoff.

Morph subs in for haste.  I think it's better than haste overall, giving a cheaper way in and pseudo-haste when you flip her over.

I don't know why, but it feels like not being able to be countered is equivalent to [autocard]Vigilance[/autocard], but in a conceptual way rather than gameplay.

And, although in creature on creature combat [autocard]Firebreathing[/autocard] isn't as valuable as First Strike, coupled with Trample it makes her that much more of a pain for the receiving opponent.

122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: Zoah
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
It's better than the other one in my opinion. Why? It can't be countered. Overall, I don't think there is a card that I'm more afraid of (Except Boil, but I have something for that) Trying to think... Nope, my main deck has absolutely no defense against this lady... Although I will admit, she looks like she would be nailed in a quick hurry by any black player.

Dangerous, but gets exponentially less useful if there is nothing black on the field, but still good. She also has a balanced price.
Final: ***** (Flashy but not broken)

122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: Vedalken_Arbiter
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
I was doing a search to see if there was a creature that was immune to nearly all types of removal.
can't be countered, Pro white, blue, toughness over 3, black and not an artifact where supposed to be my search requirments but I accidentally left out black. This was the only creature that showed up. Unfortunately, as powerful and hard to kill as this is it still dies to doomblade. I'd really love to see a super powerful creature that is immune to removal to shut up all these dies to removal fanboys.

What it needs to not die to removal:
Can't be countered.
First Strike, Protection from white, Protection from Blue
to be black
To have 5 or more toughness (Flame slash)

What it needs to be a powerhouse:
First strike, Trample, Flying
to have 5 or more power

122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: scumbling1
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
They really did a hack-job on Akroma here; her protection colors are arguably better, but everything else is worse. The white Akroma was one of the better fatties in the game, while this one is garbage.

No haste -- that right there is the single biggest problem with this card. Everyone likes Time Walk, right? Well Akroma no longer has her own.
No vigilance -- This is less important than haste, but still a disappointment. Vigilance helped her race aggro decks. What does she have in return? One of the two mutually-exclusive garbage abilities of "can't be countered" or Morph.
Firebreathing, wtf? -- Presumably you're reanimating / Oathing / otherwise cheating this into play. Do you have, or even want, to invest more mana into this card? The best fatties are self-sufficient, so this ability should be ignored in most cases.

Curious how "can't be countered" and Morph are on the same card. I really have to wonder why design choose this to be, as they conflict with each other; if you cast Akroma as a facedown creature, she doesn't have this ability and can be countered. If you just cast her through the usual method she'll never derive any benefit from her Morph ability (besides being able to turn herself face-up again after Ixidron hits play, but who cares?). That was a bad combination. And what about this "can't be countered" nonsense, anyway? Who hardcasts Akroma to begin with?

Way to take an iconic character and rub her name in the mud.

"To those of you complaining about no haste on this card... please remove your idiot hats for a moment and realize that it's from Planar Chaos. The entire set is based around color swapped abilities"

You somehow got the (incorrect) idea that I was talking about flavor rather than game mechanics. I'm not sure how you made this mistake, as it's plainly obvious that how Akroma fits into a set's theme has no relevance to how effective she is at winning a game. You should probably rein in that "idiot hat" talk, or you might start looking like a hypocrite.

122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: BegleOne
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
The morph isn't "mutually exclusive" with the "Can't be countered" ability. If you're playing against a deck that might counter it, you don't play it face-down. If you are playing a deck that won't counter it, you can pay it face down first, then flip it over the next turn for two less mana and swing away. Flexibility is a good thing; for its morph cost it's more efficient than Baneslayer.

Blue players shudder over this card. Black is what it has to worry about. If it had first strike it could kill about anything in the game one-on-one.

FANTASTIC red finisher.

122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: Nagoragama
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
Spectacular art, but far inferior to original Akroma. Morph and can't be countered have a negative interaction, if you play it as a morph it can be countered, if you hard cast it you don't get to utilize the surprise of morph. White gives her some protection from removal, but blue only helps her evade flying blockers and bounce, and she is at the mercy of black removal and red burn.

Also, everyone complaining about the lack of Haste and First Strike are missing the point of Planar Chaos. In this set, the color pie is completely mixed up, by design. The universe is coming apart, and everything is in flux. In this set, haste is a green ability and first strike is a black ability.

This Akroma is from an alternate reality where red mana means something different than what it means in the reality we know of.

122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: adrian.malacoda
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
To people saying she shouldn't have haste because she's from Planar Chaos... the original white Akroma was more off-color than this one is.

There are twelve monowhite creatures with trample (including Akroma). Most of these were printed in the early days, back when there was hardly such a thing as the color pie. The other ones are Angry Mob (makes sense... it's a mob), Bringer of the White Dawn (a creature that resurrects artifacts... quite off-color in itself?), Elder Land Wurm (trample makes sense for wurms, although wurms aren't particularly white)... and the rest are either elephants are soldiers riding on beasts. Flavorwise, trample makes sense for wurms and elephants but I have trouble imagining an angel trampling over an opponent. Although it's predominantly green, trample is more of a red ability than a white ability. It appears on large red things like dragons and elementals.

There is ONE monowhite creature with haste, which is Akroma. Although flavorwise haste makes sense for an angel of wrath (and would for an angel of fury as well), it is very far from white's philosophy. Maybe then they shouldn't have made Akroma monowhite.

122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: Missile_Penguin
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
Many of the cards in Time Spiral Block were throwbacks to at least one previously printed card. Planar Chaos featured many such homages "color-shifted" to show alternate timelines for some classic Magic stories or to demonstrate variants on the color pie (the distribution of abilities and effects which spells can and can't do.)

This card is represents an Akroma, Angel of Wrath from a timeline where Ixidor, Reality Scultor is a vicious dark wizard who creates an Akroma bent on destroying the world!

122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.author: FlashCaster
122432: Akroma, Angel of Fury.text_parsed:
She is a good card but isn't really the best designed honestly. Morph doesn't make much sense on this card to me, especially considering that she can't be countered. The biggest problem though is the lack of first strike, because no matter how much you pump her up she will still die in combat to many 6+ power fliers.

Considering that she carries the name Akroma I was expecting a little more, but hey versus the right deck she can be extremely punishing. She is the only creature that can't be countered, has protection from blue, and has flying all in one. This is a strange card to rate because she does have a lot going on, but honestly I feel it isn't enough. First strike was the way to go instead of morph, but even haste or vigilance at the very least would have made her a lot more epic. I still like her so much that I bought a foil one which resides in my 140 card 5 color deck, and her foil wasn't exactly cheap.

4.5/5

122434: Imp's Mischief.author: Excaelezar
122434: Imp's Mischief.text_parsed:
202.3b When calculating the converted mana cost of an object with an {X} in its mana cost, X is treated as 0 while the object is not on the stack, and X is treated as the number chosen for it while the object is on the stack.

For banefire you'll lose 1 more life but on the bright side you're opponent will lose life too since banefire will hit them.
122434: Imp's Mischief.text_posted:

122434: Imp's Mischief.author: absreim
122434: Imp's Mischief.text_parsed: I think this card is far better than it initially looks. Keep in the mind that Misdrection effects are often a 2 for 1 when you use it on a removal spell. Like all Misdirection effects, this card can counter counterspells and has the potential to answer uncounterable spells like abrupt decay and remove your opponent's hexproof permanents. Besides being in black, which normally does not have access to such effects, it is much easier to cast than the blue and red equivalents, Redirect, Shunt, and Swerve, each of which require two colored mana.
122434: Imp's Mischief.text_posted: I think this card is far better than it initially looks. 122438: Heroes Remembered.author: TheSwarm
122438: Heroes Remembered.text_parsed: This card is responsible for the greatest comeback i have or will ever make. It was a casual game, I had a Wall Of Reverence and Cradle of Vitality out and suspended this around the fourth or fifth turn. In retrospect probably not the best idea, however without it I wouldn't have won. Basically, it put a huge target on my chest. So the two other guys spent their time coming after me, but because of the life gain from the wall I got and some of the odd blockers and spells like Safe Passage I barely BARELY lasted to one life. This finally dropped and I got 20 life, Activated Cradle Of Vitality, obtained a 33/39 Wall Of Reverence, and proceeded to increase my life to a whopping 2200. Would have gotten more, except I just didn't even boother at that point. Most epic moment of my entire magic life. Oh, with a 2200 power Blinding Angel, hehehe. Heeeee wouldve been bigger too, but someone blammed my cradle of vitality

122438: Heroes Remembered.author: sarroth
122438: Heroes Remembered.text_parsed: It is true that usually lifegain does not allow you to win, as it only prolongs the inevitable. Nonetheless, my best memory from my first games of Magic were hardcasting 2 of these in the same game. The deck had a few tough cards such as Akroma, Angel of Wrath that might have helped win the game if I had drawn them. Surely with the mention of Sanguine Bond and with the newer Serra Ascendant and Felidar Soverign this card has a place in casual decks more than just to prolong your defeat. But even without them, the stories can be fun.

It happens enough. This is your card and it helps.

122438: Heroes Remembered.author: DoragonShinzui
122438: Heroes Remembered.text_parsed:
The nice thing about this card is if you drop it on turn one, your opponents will more often than not quake in fear at the...life gain spell you have.
So long as you can keep yourself more or less alive, this allows for a bit more of an aggressive play, as it costs less than nothing to suspend and can be used to frighten your opponents. And, really, mind games is where most of the victory is at.

122442: Serendib Sorcerer.author: jsttu
122442: Serendib Sorcerer.text_parsed:
I love this card, and it reminds me of ovinomancer, almost as if this guy is the apprentice, unable to do it permanently. Consequently, whenever he transforms someone into a sheep (or whatever, but i like to think of it as a sheep) I have to let out a loud 'BAAAAAA!'. With an ability as fun/weird as this, someone has to. The great part is the people in my playgroup have started to as well. Awesome.

About the card itself, I have also found good utility with Merfolk Thaumaturgist, as well as blinking a Spawnbroker in and out of play, exchanging itself for the 0/2, then blinking it so it comes back under my control to repeat the action. If in a tight spot you can always use it to nullify an attacker or make a combat exchange more profitable, although as you are playing blue control that is less likely. No matter what, this is an amazing card that is excellent in multiples, and any blue creature-based control deck should run multiple copies..

122442: Serendib Sorcerer.author: JaxsonBateman
122442: Serendib Sorcerer.text_parsed:
Decent pseudo-removal card on its own (pumps aside, it more or less removes a creature as a suitable attacker/blocker, and can switch as your opponent plays more creatures), but works best in conjunction with other cards. Like people have mentioned, combos well with Thaumaturgist, but that card itself isn't very good without help, whereas Serendib can stand up on its own.

It does adore Beguiler of Wills from Dark Ascension though. Easy, permanent mind control.

122459: Spellshift.author: PeabodyET
122459: Spellshift.text_parsed:
@XDaragoX: The deck that this was begging for is one that I played in standard back in RAV/TSP. Basically, you get Eye of the Storm in play, then put a spell on it, say Sleight of Hand. Then when you get the copy, you counter it with Spellshift. Eye will exile your Spellshift, you can stack the Sleight and counter it with the copy of Spellshift. This will let you reveal cards from your library and cast the next instant or sorcery. When you cast it, Eye will exile it and you'll get to stack all three spells. Just stack Sleight and Spellshift again, and you'll end up putting every instant and sorcery in your library on Eye, and a crazy number of copies of each of the early spells.

As long as you have something like Careful Consideration on there, you can deck your opponent easily. You can also stack a bunch of copies of Walk the Aeons to take as many turns as you wanted. You could make the deck a lockout if you got Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir in play, which means that if you opponent played an instant or sorcery, during their turn of course, Eye would exile it and give them copies, but Teferi wouldn't allow them to actually play the copies.

Back before the changes to "exile vs remove from game", you could even have a Research (Research//Development) in there, which could take spell cards off of the Eye and put them back in your library to go super-infinite. I suppose you can do the same thing if you run some flashback spells and Runic Repetition. Or you can use Pull from Eternity and Mnemonic Nexus.

122459: Spellshift.author: Enelysios
122459: Spellshift.text_parsed:
This card was almost great, but its still Johnny fodder. At less it would have been broken (For it's ability to cast on yourself) so it had to sit here, not really usable on an opponent, and rather hard to effectively work with on yourself. I am making a casual deck around this and Either Biorythm, Decree of Pain, or (Most likely) Sway of the Stars.

The idea is that I cast Selective memory, and remove all other instants and sorceries from my deck, then probably on my next turn I tap all my lands, filling my mana pool, cast something like Gitixian Probe, then cast this, having Sway of the Stars as the only other instant/sorcery in the deck. When it hits, we basically restart the game at 7 life and I can use whatever mana I still have in my mana pool to cast something mean and kill my weakened opponent.

The other components include classic green ramp and suspended cards to come in after sway of the stars is cast.

Similar to many polymorph decks, but with the main drawbacsk being that it is very fragile for that last turn and that the two main components cost . Still, having creatures in the deck gives it an advantage over polymorph decks, and all that you need in hand to get it is a selective memory, spellshift and any other sorcery. Oh, and the deck costs like $8.

I could also see the following working in a deck like this: Plague Wind, Vitalizing wind, Searing Wind or Army of the Damned. I am still playing around with it.

122468: Wild Pair.author: Donovan_Fabian
122468: Wild Pair.text_parsed: What I think is really awesome about this card is the only requirement is same power and toughness, meaning I can zoom in to using a spellbreaker after I play this, which only costs 4 mana, and go find something that costs 6 or 7 but is still a 5/5, like a flameblast dragon.  That is some cool stuff once you get the ball rolling, you can play two really massive creatures a turn.  Your opponent might counter spell one or two but eventually they will run out, and on top of that you can use creatures like the spellbreaker I just suggested to automatically trigger the second creature, that is now uncounterable because of my first one.  I imagine even a 3 mana thoctar could find some good use for this, there are a lot of nice 5/4's with an ability, and even if you use it only to get a second thoctar, you still have 2, 5/4's in play in one turn.  It may cost 6 mana, but thats pretty easy in green, and your investment doubles every turn you keep it in play.

122468: Wild Pair.author: applecorn
122468: Wild Pair.text_parsed:
@ArKive
if read the oracle rulings, it explains your question. it checks all spells, abilities and other modifies on the field and those coming into play. once it has finally hit the battlefield it will allow you to look in your library for your creature. as for putting a 1/1 into play when Might is already there, it would be a 3/3 entering the battlefield. 0/6, 1/5, 2/4, 3/3, 4/2, 5/1, 6/X (since X=O) would all be valid searches.

Improbable Combo:
Have Wild Pair out. You have at least 6 mana.
Cast Master Biomancer (P/T = 2/3), pair with another Master Biomancer (P/T = 2/3, but gets 2 counters from the other Biomancer).
Cast Sage of Hours (P/T = 1/1, but gets 6 counters from the Biomancers), pair with Novablast Wurm (P/T = 7/7, but gets 6 counters from the Biomancers).

Take an extra turn. Destroy all other creatures and attack with your 13/13.

122469: Stonecloaker.author: Tommy9898
122469: Stonecloaker.text_parsed: A very useful card in multiplayer. At the end of the turn you can flash him down, eat a card in a grave then bounce him back, so it is essentially 2W remove a card from a graveyard. You can also play it in response to some nasty Reanimate type spell or just use it to Rescue a better creature. It is so versatile, just make sure your deck can make plenty of mana.

122469: Stonecloaker.author: swords_to_exile
122469: Stonecloaker.text_parsed: This card is an allstar in EDH.  Graveyard effects are major threats in White, Blue and Black - the most played EDH colours.  The instant speed targeted removal is powerful enough to include it on it's own, but the bounce ability allows me to remove multiple cards, or to save something from a kill-spell aimed at one of me creatures.  this card is a solid 4.5 in normal play, and 5 in EDH.
122469: Stonecloaker.text_posted: This card is an allstar in EDH.  Graveyard effects are major threats in White, Blue and Black - the most played EDH colours. 122469: Stonecloaker.author: Ligerman30
122469: Stonecloaker.text_parsed: If you are on the fence about this card in your edh deck, even just ignoring the 4th ability this card his bounce ability at instant speed is super relevant . You can save your best guy from a wrath or counter targeted removal. Maybe your opponent forces you to attack or block with a creature, you can save that creature from combat. You can bounce something like a Kor Sanctifier and get the effect again. It's also a dude with evasion so you will be able to attack all day with it. Works well with something like Primordial Sage to draw some cards or Warstorm Surge and kill some stuff. But the best part is when you are playing against an EDH deck that abuses graveyards heavily and you can just be all like "Oops stonecloaker, return stonecloaker", over and over again. But, even if you know the decks you are playing against don't really use the graveyard at all, you are still going to be able to get value out of it. It might be a bit slow for other formats, but, in edh this card does really have it's moments, being able to stop infinite combos (Like infinitely sac/recurring eternal witness to get back time warp) is really an invaluable asset to any edh deck that plans to be successful.

In my R/W deck:

Cosmic Larva+Bloodthorn Taunter+ This=
Repeated 7/6 attacks

1- Play Bloodthorn Taunter
2- Play Cosmic Larva and haste it using bloodthorn taunter
3- Just before its beginning of your upkeep again, play Whitemane Lion to unsummon Cosmic Larva and resume the attacks :)

122477: Whitemane Lion.author: kiseki
122477: Whitemane Lion.text_parsed:
A strong flexible, NON-TARGETING card. I consider it for every mono white deck, and others besides. I love having aura shards out with this. It becomes a reusable disenchant. If the other player never targets your stuff, you can still use it to get your come into play effects working again.
This is better than the stonecloaker. It has 90% of the power for 67% of the cost. You do get more for the extra colorless mana, but since it is a responsive creature, you need to leave mana untapped, and I would rather have that extra mana to spend during my turn. If you have something like the shards or pandemonium out, you can run this more often.
122477: Whitemane Lion.text_posted:
A strong flexible, NON-TARGETING card.  I consider it for every mono white deck, and others besides.  I love having [autocard]aura shards[/autocard] out with this.  It becomes a reusable disenchant.  If the other player never targets your stuff, you can still use it to get your come into play effects working again.  
This is better than the [autocard]stonecloaker[/autocard].  It has 90% of the power for 67% of the cost.  You do get more for the extra colorless mana, but since it is a responsive creature, you need to leave mana untapped, and I would rather have that extra mana to spend during my turn.  If you have something like the shards or pandemonium out, you can run this more often.

122477: Whitemane Lion.author: Kontrah
122477: Whitemane Lion.text_parsed:
This worked so well with other Vanishing creatures from the same set. When Planar Chaos was released, a friend made a pretty sollid R/W Boros style deck that ran most of the red/white Vanishing cards and a suite of burns. Between Lion and Momentary Blink, you end up with a lot of activations for Keldon Marauder, Aven Rif***cher, Stingscourger, and a surprisingly resilient Calciderm.

This was much more difficult to deal with pre-M10 of course...but even now, those ETB/LTB triggers are still fairly powerful, and the Lion is one of the most recyclable.

122487: Crovax, Ascendant Hero.author: Mode
122487: Crovax, Ascendant Hero.text_parsed:
(old comment:)
When regarding this card i don't know whether i should wonder why this card, being the very only timeshifted legend ever, does not use the planeshift-design; or whether i should rather wonder why Ascendant Evincar, the card this timeshifted version is based on, did not get his actual name mentioned on the card back then as they did with his newer as well as his older self, Crovax The Cursed.

Nontheless i like this card, and not just for flavor reasons like representing the third impersonation of the same character.

(edit:)
Ok, i admit i screwed up.
It was stupid from me to somehow regard them as identical regarding functionality.
One of them is a 3/3 flyer, the other a 4/4 with optional bounce.

But neither is Akroma, Angel of Fury a planeshifted version of Akroma, Angel of Wrath, nor is Mirri the Cursed a planeshifted version of Mirri, Cat Warrior, nor is Braids, Conjourer Adept a planeshifted version of Braids, Cabal Minion regarding functionality.
You wouldn't call Jeska, Warrior Adept a planeshifted version of Phage the Untouchable or Kamahl, Fist of Krosa a planeshifted version of Kamahl, Pit Fighter either.

I considered Crovax, Ascendant Hero to be an identical white version of Ascendant Evincar.
And therefore i wondered why he didn't get the planeshift card frame.
That's what this entire fuzz was about.
Don't think i didn't know about the other Legends that reappeared in this block.

122487: Crovax, Ascendant Hero.author: sonorhC
122487: Crovax, Ascendant Hero.text_parsed:
A bit late, but in response to jumpenrun: Unless stated otherwise, abilities of permanents only function while they're on the battlefield, so no, you can't use his ability from the graveyard. You can, however, use it in response to something that would kill him, in which case he never goes to the graveyard at all.

And since nobody else has mentioned it, he's rather outclassed now by Elesh Norn, Grand Cenobite, who costs only more, and gets +1/+3 compared to him, has double the bonus/penalty, and benefits all your creatures and hurts all opponents' creatures, regardless of color.
122487: Crovax, Ascendant Hero.text_posted:
A bit late, but in response to jumpenrun:  Unless stated otherwise, abilities of permanents only function while they're on the battlefield, so no, you can't use his ability from the graveyard.  You can, however, use it in response to something that would kill him, in which case he never goes to the graveyard at all.

 And since nobody else has mentioned it, he's rather outclassed now by [autocard]Elesh Norn, Grand Cenobite[/autocard], who costs only [1] more, and gets +1/+3 compared to him, has double the bonus/penalty, and benefits all your creatures and hurts all opponents' creatures, regardless of color.

124040: Brain Gorgers.author: N03y3D33R
124040: Brain Gorgers.text_parsed:
I love the art and flavor for this card.
A zombie horde that hungers for brains and will doggedly pursue them no matter what. The only way to dissuade them from eating your face is shoving your minions into the undead horde to pacify them, at least until they inevitably come back for more.
These guys work well with cards like Undertaker, who not only give you an excuse to discard, but can continually cycle these beasties and anything else you want back into your hand to play or discard again.
A lot like browbeat, this is the kind of card you play when you really want to probe your opponent during one of their slow turns and see how they respond to it.
If I remember correctly this card came in a theme deck featuring cards like the madness enchantment Gibbering Descent, which empties everyones hands over time, an effect that definitely puts someone under pressure, particularly if you slam them with a Psychotic Episode and nab one of their immediate response cards.

Ultimately I think these guys have a very narrow niche, and Phantasmagorian fills that niche better than they do for many reasons. Nonetheless, these guys are an awesome example of creativity in the zombie creature type and hold a special place in my heart. Not to mention, they have a great synergy with discard/burn cards like Firestorm or Mercurial Chemister.

124055: Wistful Thinking.author: igniteice
124055: Wistful Thinking.text_parsed:
I played this on an opponent who had three cards in his hand. One of the cards was Twincast, which he used on my Wistful Thinking. He of course targeted me with his copy. I had 5 cards in my hand after casting, so I ended up choosing 3 of 7. He, having used Twincast, was down to 2, and had to discard his entire hand.

The basic premise then is that if your opponent has two or less cards, they're going to lose their hand. If you have 3 or more cards, you'll at least get to keep 1 card. In a bind, that's better than nothing, as it gives this card versatility. Most of the time I'm using it to force my opponent to discard. You could run this in a dredge, madness, or flashback deck though and have pretty good success with it, especially for cards that care about casting from graveyards (Burning Vengeance, Secrets of the Dead).

124055: Wistful Thinking.author: Splizer
124055: Wistful Thinking.text_parsed:
OK, moderately stylish Turn 4 win incoming.

Turn 1: Swamp/Island

Turn 2: Swamp/Island, Liliana's Caress

Turn 3: Swamp/Island, Megrim

Turn 4: Swamp/Island, 1 mana discard spell of your choice (dealing 4 damage/life loss) Wistful Thinking (dealing 16 damage/life loss).

TA-DAA! That's 20 in one hit! This combo isn't too hard to pull off either; run a decent two-colour manabase, 4 Caresses and a few Megrims and the 4 Wistful Thinking can dish out more damage than Mind Rot.

124057: Vorosh, the Hunter.author: holgir
124057: Vorosh, the Hunter.text_parsed:
@all:
Well, seems like Thaxan_Number_14's lousy comment backfired a bit, good to see. :-)

@Card:
Vorosh's ability certainly is the "timmiest" of all these three-coloured dragon legends and was therefore underestimated and considered dumb at first. Fact is that all 10 dragons (if you are counting the five versions from Invasion as Arachibutyrophobia did) just take out a blocker and do nothing else if something gets in their way. But, as FirstPrime has already suggested, Vorosh can end the game alone in very short order if he stays unchecked (he is the only one who just needs to hit three times, the other nine dragons need four attacks). Resistance to most black removal helps and if you can activate his ability just once, he should be out of reach for red damage spells. Last but not least: great artwork.

124057: Vorosh, the Hunter.author: TheMurderousKitten
124057: Vorosh, the Hunter.text_parsed:
@ TPmanW:
The reason no one mentioned Soul's Fire is because Vorosh's ability requires combat damage and Soul's Fire does not deal combat damage. It would be decent after you have already pumped Vorosh a time or two, but would not allow you to use his ability to pump himself.

With blue, black and green, you should be able to get him through for combat damage without much problem. You can give him fear, trample or simply make him unblockable with those colors. And he's already flying anyway. Shouldn't really need to resort to spells like Soul's Fire.
124057: Vorosh, the Hunter.text_posted:

The reason no one mentioned Soul's Fire is because Vorosh's ability requires combat damage and Soul's Fire does not deal combat damage.  It would be decent after you have already pumped Vorosh a time or two, but would not allow you to use his ability to pump himself.

124062: Numot, the Devastator.author: Donovan_Fabian
124062: Numot, the Devastator.text_parsed: This card is amazing in early game and terrible in late game, by late game your opponent probably has blockers/creature removal, and you would have to spend a lot of turns bringing down their lands even if you could get your dragon through, at which point its a normal 6/6 flyer for 6 mana.  On the flip side, if you play it very early with mana accel and your opponent doesn't have a flying blocker, you can pretty much assume you just won the game.  Its risk vs. reward.

124062: Numot, the Devastator.author: bokwinkle0
124062: Numot, the Devastator.text_parsed:
Decent card. It's 6/6 with slight evasion (flying isn't all that evasive anymore) for 6 mana - pretty standard when it comes to legendary dragons. I find the ability pretty decent, but destroying mana starting on turn 7 seems slightly weak. Although in EDH (the only format where this card would probably EVER be played) turn 7 LD may be 'ok' - if you can somehow get him through for damage and keep him alive.

Generally though, I find him way too easy to deal with with the quality of answers availble in the formats he can be used in. In the White and Blue colors I would expect some defense on this guy - some sort of shroud, or deflection ability...something useful to keep him alive. In red...I'd expect it to be slightly more aggressive - laying a slow creature on turn 6 isn't what red does well. When I look at this card I can't find a place that he really fits...so that's why I give him 2-1/2 stars.

Honestly, when I look at this card I compare him to the other R/W/U creatures out there - Lightning angel. 3 Abilities, 3 colors. Evasion for bule (flying), defense for white (vig), aggressiveness for red (haste), and a 3/4 body because he's so tough to cast. The reality is that Numot doesn't hold a candle to that design.

Speaking of formats - it's the only available EDH general in it's given colors....kinda sad.

124062: Numot, the Devastator.author: OmegaSerris
124062: Numot, the Devastator.text_parsed:
Land destruction (or at least disruption) has been in all colors in some form over the years. Yes, is most famous for it, but has had it's fair share. Though it took the typical approach of 'fair' destuction where equal number (Balance) or all lands (Armageddon).

on the other hand usually disrupts land, more than destroying it. Bouncing (Boomerang) or tapping ( Mana Short) lands to slow to even lock out an opponent's resources. But I agree that this is pushing it for the side of Numot.

On a side note, why are spells automatically associated only with America? I'm American myself, so I somewhat get it, but there are a ton of countries represented by those colors on their flags. United Kingdom, France, Chile... and even Russia and Cuba. Does that mean Nayans are Mexican or Italian? Or is Jund in Afghanistan? Just something that irked me to see on every comment page.

124062: Numot, the Devastator.author: DacenOctavio
124062: Numot, the Devastator.text_parsed: This is a superb EDH general. Played right, he keeps opposing generals off the battlefield because they can't afford the climbing mana cost of their legend when they're losing 2 lands a turn. I've won so many end-game control mirrors this way. In this man's colors, you have access to countless wraths, bounces, and burns that it quickly becomes an epic duel to the death between Numot and whatever unfortunate legend they've mustered behind. It usually ain't pretty for them.

124066: Piracy Charm.author: Gezus82
124066: Piracy Charm.text_parsed:
ok. why is this rated so low? this charm is amazing. granted the first ability is kind of useless, the others are really nice.
firstly, instant speed discard on 1 manna is great, especially for blue that normally makes a player draw before discarding.

but the real reason this card shines is the +2/-1. this effect alone is incredibly versatile:

=firstly as incredibly effective blue removal. I don't know how many times I'v used this card to kill llowanar elves, noble higherarch's, birds of paradise, ad that's just first turn plays. sure it's not the best removal but in mono blue I find it very helpful to be able to strait kill things instead of playing around with boomerangs and counterspells, the 1 mana especially helps here to kill the things that come down before you have the mana for counterspells.

-secondly the pumping is very nice as well and comes through a lot for game winning damage. 4 damage from a fantom warrior or a mulldrifter or 6 from an air elemental one of my best memories is stacking 3 of these on an air elemental for 10 damage.

and the possibility of unblockability on for 1 manna is not bad.

So I've just convinced myself that this is a bad card. It's ridiculously good for blue aggro. and blue should not do aggro.
bad card. goes against all things blue. (except maybe the islandwalk)

124066: Piracy Charm.author: IndubitableSalmon
124066: Piracy Charm.text_parsed:
Instant speed discard alone would be pretty great already, but no, this beaut sports a few additional options too:
- Kills target creature with toughness 1, ignores indestructible, no regeneration possible.
- Deals 2 damage to target player that was dealt damage by a creature this turn.
- If your opponent conrols an island, target creature you control is unblockable until end of turn.

Indubitally the second most powerful charm - not only in blue - it only has to bow before the mighty Vision Charm itself.

124073: Intet, the Dreamer.author: AitrusX
124073: Intet, the Dreamer.text_parsed:
I use this as a general for an EDH deck. The main limitation is that she doesn't allow you to play the spells at special times - if you find a creature you must play it during your turn on a main phase (unless of course it has flash), lands can only be played on your turn, sorceries only on your turn.

So when you get the card from her ability, usually if you can play it on your turn you do - because if you risk leaving it out of play as a bluff intet might be killed on another players turn and then you don't get to play that creature/sorcery/land at all.
124073: Intet, the Dreamer.text_posted:

124073: Intet, the Dreamer.author: MacBizzle
124073: Intet, the Dreamer.text_parsed:
I already have a UGR EDH deck assembled. I sent an important question to WotC about this card though. Say someone does something to make Intet go into the command zone (or just off the battlefield altogether), if- I mean WHEN I play Intet again, will I have access to the already exiled cards? I'm pretty sure I do, but it occurred to me that they might make me make a new pile of cards, with the older pile being completely useless.

EDIT: I emailed a Wizards Representative. They clarified that the older cards are in fact unusable as soon as Intet leaves play, and replaying Intet will be a new Intet. BTW, who gave me half a star like I didn't know what I was talking about without even replying to tell me what I had said that was so stupid?

124073: Intet, the Dreamer.author: DarthParallax
124073: Intet, the Dreamer.text_parsed:
Like Dromar before her, the Blue-centric Legendary Dragon of the cycle requires you to carefully think and build your deck with real strategy other than looking up "Color = My Commander's Color Identity"; "Rating = >3.56" on Gatherer. I like cards like that :) But I also think I ONLY like them in Blue-based stuff, since the game is actually complicated enough without making the cards difficult to see what you want to do with them.

They should KEEP making Blue like they used to make Old Fashioned MTG, but Green and Red, frankly it's ok that they hit you over the head with Timminess/Titanlike stuff now. :P

White and Black are strange animals, that lack some definition but each make up for in potential. If R&D want to please as many people as possible with the game as a whole, White and Black need to remain bridges between the Big Dumb Monsters and the Clever Spellbook approach. While the balance has nearly been kept, Power Creep seems to me to be most dangerous for these colors (they will never powercreep Blue again after The Mind Sculptor. They are justified to kind of be in a State of War with Blue thanks to that, and no amount of powercreeping creatures will really be able to change the fact that there are always answers for Creatures that cost 3 mana or less: Either Counter it, Destroy it, Discard it, or Exile it from the Graveyard-works on everything.) So Black and White are the colors that people should be most concerned about, since the other 3 are kind of pretty much s cripted at this point.

124073: Intet, the Dreamer.author: DacenOctavio
124073: Intet, the Dreamer.text_parsed:
We seriously need more {URG} Wedge cards. I think the planar chaos dragons, and other legends of the Time Spiral block were perfectly balanced. I've seen the weird stuff that got printed in Commander and Planechase and weep at the level of powercreep Wizards crammed into the casual sector.

Maelstrom Wanderer seems kind of OP for often giving his controller free Time Warps, Temporal Masterys, and titans. Zedruu draws an abnormally large amount of cards while gaining extraordinary amounts of life. The Nin decks in my meta get away with shooting Stuffy Doll, grumble grumble.

124075: Teneb, the Harvester.author: PhyrexianLobbiest
124075: Teneb, the Harvester.text_parsed:
Thank you Tezz, I was thinking the same thing while reading this. I use Teneb in my G/W/B attrition deck, since the deck is highly reactionary and focuses more on stopping the opponent and keeping my life total stable I have an easy time surviving my opponents attacks, but a difficult time killing them back.

Teneb solves this problem elegantly, by being a 6/6 flyer himself, and by allowing me to steal their heavy hitters from the graveyard for 3. Consider that you get to put that creature into play under your control UNTIL IT DIES. Teneb let's you play incredibly expensive creatures for almost nothing- creatures that don't even have to be yours!

124075: Teneb, the Harvester.author: froggytherock
124075: Teneb, the Harvester.text_parsed:
lets compare him to charnelhoard wurm:
Charnelhoard wurm can:
bring back himself
bring back any card in your library (including removal cards)
has trample, which makes him more likely to do combat damage to a player
isn't legendary, so you can have more than one on the field
doesn't require mana to use his effect
doesn't have to give combat damage, just any old damage to use his effect. anything with "tap this creature: it deals 1 damage to target player" works

Teneb:
is 1 less mana
can target any graveyard
but can only bring back creatures, but on the up side they go on the field, not in your hand

124075: Teneb, the Harvester.author: ChampionofSquee

The deck features a ton of reanimation just in case he or my siege tower dies lol. if you ever have trouble choosing who to Breath of LIfe and Teneb is a choice then you deserve to be hit for not instantly chosing him. I think he's the best of the timeshifted primevals. Intet is also nice, but his ability has the option of getting you a CMC <3 card and then its just a waste of a few mana. Unless you have a problem building decks, Teneb will just about always end up bringing back a huge hitter and changing the game around instantly.
