134743: Dreamscape Artist.author: Lyoncet
134743: Dreamscape Artist.text_parsed:
Gets a 5/5 from me for several reasons. It's blue mana acceleration that lasts more than one turn and isn't completely broken and banned. It effectively only costs 1 colorless to activate, since the lands come into play untapped. (As d101 mentioned, you actually gain mana out of this if you have Training Grounds.) Plus the mana fixing lets you run fewer CIP tapped fetchlands like Terramorphic Expanse if you'd otherwise need them, which speeds up your game even further. And of course once he's done, he's a fine chump blocker.

Seriously if you put him in a mono-blue deck with High Tide, you can have 13 available mana on turn 4 (four normal land drops, use him on turn 3, use him again on turn 4 since you'll get 4 mana from the two lands because of High Tide since that applies to lands that come into play even after it resolves). That's turn 4. In blue. That just doesn't happen! And since this is blue we're talking about, you're likely going to have draw spells up the wazoo, giving you something productive to do with all that mana. Really, you just can't do better than this in non-artifact blue without cheating.

134743: Dreamscape Artist.author: Enelysios
134743: Dreamscape Artist.text_parsed:
Okay, he won't be seeing any tournement play I suppose. Spellshapers haven't fared well in that regard ever. While the effect is similar, he is actually a lot weaker than Harrow. Why?

1.) He is delayed a turn after you play him.
2.) You have to risk to put him out for future use.
3.) He himself is a card, then a second card is required to activate his ability.

That said, he is blue. Blue is the color with the worst mana acceleration (for good reason!) so the scarcity there makes him a lot more valuable than he would have been in green. The re-usability is nice as well, but mostly in EDH or other slow formats. He is too slow to see much use elsewhere anyway, but should be a top pick for mono-blue EDH decks.

134743: Dreamscape Artist.author: NissasChosen
134743: Dreamscape Artist.text_parsed:
This is one of my pet cards. It's in most of my blue decks. Planar Chaos is my favorite set. I should stop explaining the color pie to new players.
"See, blue is all about ramp and big creatures, as proven by my Training Grounds deck with Dreamscape Artist, Ludevic's Test Subject and Sphinx of Magosi. Green is all about doing as much damage as fast as possible, demonstrated in this deck with Groundbreaker, Wild Defiance, pump spells Primal Forcemage and Timbermare. Red is all about defense and control until a big finish as proven by this deck with Aether Membrane, Dead // Gone, Pyrohemia, and Scourge of Kher Ridges."
I haven't really broken black or white's color pie yet, but I plan on it.
134743: Dreamscape Artist.text_posted:
This is one of my pet cards. It's in most of my blue decks. Planar Chaos is my favorite set. I should stop explaining the color pie to new players.
"See, blue is all about ramp and big creatures, as proven by my [autocard]Training Grounds[/autocard] deck with Dreamscape Artist, [autocard]Ludevic's Test Subject[/autocard] and [autocard]Sphinx of Magosi[/autocard]. Green is all about doing as much damage as fast as possible, demonstrated in this deck with [autocard]Groundbreaker[/autocard], [autocard]Wild Defiance[/autocard], pump spells [autocard]Primal Forcemage[/autocard] and [autocard]Timbermare[/autocard]. Red is all about defense and control until a big finish as proven by this deck with [autocard]Aether Membrane[/autocard], [autocard]Dead // Gone[/autocard], [autocard]Pyrohemia[/autocard], and [autocard]Scourge of Kher Ridges[/autocard]."
I haven't really broken black or white's color pie yet, but I plan on it.

134746: Magus of the Arena.author: Missile_Penguin
134746: Magus of the Arena.text_parsed:
Nearly every card in Time Spiral block was a throwback to at least one previously printed card.

This card references Arena and is part of the "Magus" super cycle of rare creatures. The cards in Planar Chaos all reference one of the most powerful lands ever; the others are Magus of the Bazaar, Magus of the Coffers, Magus of the Tabernacle, and Magus of the Library.

The Time Spiral part of the cycle focuses on powerful artifacts: Magus of the Candelabra, Magus of the Disk, Magus of the Mirror, Magus of the Jar, and Magus of the Scroll. The Future Sight part of the cycle focuses on powerful enchantments: Magus of the Moat, Magus of the Future, Magus of the Abyss, Magus of the Moon, and Magus of the Vineyard.
134746: Magus of the Arena.text_posted:

136170: Oros, the Avenger.author: darkfury
136170: Oros, the Avenger.text_parsed:
Oros has many combos with enchants in this game. some of the best options to put on Oros are Lifelink, Vampiric Link/Spirit Link, and Soul link.
another good enchantment to stick on him is Fists of the Demigod, which gives him Wither and First strike. With Wither, Oros conflagrates the field with holy flames, scaring all non-white creatures with 3 -1/-1 counters. other enchants, such as Scourge of the Nobilis give Oros Firebreathing (which makes him even more dragon-y) and lifelink. Oros+Lifelink+Wither=health funnel. Daybreak Coronet if placed on Oros while he has Fists on gives him +3/+3, vigilance and lifelink. Oros and the Quietus Spike are incredible at clearing boards, hyper-powering his triggered ability.

do not put Sword of Fire and Ice of Sword of Light and Shadow on Oros, the inability to enchant Oros means he returns to his pre-Shadowmoor crappy self. bit of history here: Oros was printed before any cards that even remotely made him playable had been sent for design had survived or even been conceived

another great card to put on Oros is the rare Artifact Blade of the Bloodchief. this card gives the equiped creature Rockslide Elemental/Scavenger Drake/Deathbringer Thoctar's ability to harvest +1/+1 counters from dead enemies. Honestly, with a simple Fists of the Demigod, he is already a god, although his total dominance of the board just feels like he is an insult to your opponent's complete deck. and he simply is letting you live so you can provide entertainment to him.

need i give any more reasons as to why he owns?

136170: Oros, the Avenger.author: Thornhillforge
136170: Oros, the Avenger.text_parsed:
So, flavor-wise, I wonder what white-black-red looks like. I would imagine that it is a sort of over zealous, prejudiced belief in one's own supremacy. And due to the red/white aspect, I would say that it would have a sort of 'crusade'-mentality where it fights almost religiously to preserve its own purity. (Probably it wouldn't be seen as 'pure' by anyone else, but a R/B/W creature probably doesn't care much what others think).
Does anyone else have an idea of what RBW would look like?
